posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked:
Hello, I’m new here and I’m excited to be part of this community, which I’ve heard is a great place to connect with the public. I’m not entirely sure about the norms or formal customs here, so any guidance would be helpful.  

My team (Team 6343) has been working with Python for a while now, and we’re considering a move to Java. While we know Java offers some cool new technical features, I’m concerned about ensuring a smooth transition. I’d love to understand the key advantages and potential challenges, as well as the major differences beyond syntax. Any insights you could share would be greatly appreciated!  

Thank you in advance for your help.  
Chima

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: I think a lot of the pros of Java come from its strong community support. It’s gonna be the easiest to find example code using Java, and it’ll be simpler to copy code from top teams in past years since they mostly use Java as well. It’s also easier to get help with code problems since Java is the most well-known language in FIRST. One thing new to us this year was logging through Epilogue. Adding the annotation to the top of the class makes logging easy and automatic, which really helped with debugging. To gain experience, you could also reprogram your robot in Java now to get a head start on programming for next season. Good luck, and let me know if you have any questions!

link_counts.title: New for 2025: Robot Telemetry with Annotations (Java Only) — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked: Thank you for your input, especially regarding logging. We’re coming from AdvantageScope and I’ve heard of Advantage Kit. Do you know how that compares to Epilogue? Also, thanks for the idea of reprogramming our robot—I’ll likely bring that up with our mentor.

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: AdvantageKit is more complex to set up but offers benefits such as simulation replay. It requires significant changes to the code structure, particularly in its input-output layers and configuration, whereas the Epilogue simply adds a single line to the top of each subsystem file.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: What would you say is your team’s experience level with Java? Does your team have mentors or members with a solid background in Java? Or are you all still learning?

posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked: Our main programming mentor is pretty much fluent in Java but is relatively new to robotics, having only been involved for his first year.

posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked: Would you say that the setup and different code structure are worth the benefits or is it something that is an offseason project in itself? And if we were all learning Java fresh, couldn’t we incorporate the IO layers and the extra knowledge in the learning process?

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: I haven’t used AdvantageKit personally, and for our team this year, it wasn’t worth it. Epilogue provided everything we needed except for Sim Replay. Whether the additional features of AdvantageKit are worth it for you is something you’ll have to decide. I’d recommend watching the video recording of the 6328 Champs presentation to help you make that decision.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
There are some great resources to get started with "robot" programming, and having someone experienced with Java should make those resources pretty easy to follow. The off-season is definitely the right time to be looking into this. If you run into any unexpected trouble, you can always fall back to using Python for another year.

Check out these instructional videos: https://youtube.com/@0toauto?si=B1A6XaTu2SXUFav-.

posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked: Alright, sounds good, thank you so much for the input!

posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked: Oh, this looks really helpful. Thank you so much for your help!

posts.name: Dylan Li
posts.cooked: Last year, 1076 was in the same spot, and we documented its transition from timed-based Python to command-based Java. Here’s an emoji of a slight smile: :slight_smile:. We converted the WPilib swerve template to work with a REV drivetrain before moving on to AdvantageKit, allowing us to gradually build up our understanding of command-based programming and Java. This approach ensures a smoother transition compared to jumping straight into AdvantageKit. While it requires more code, having enough time during school or the offseason helps manage this process. If time is limited, splitting the transition into two years—one focused on command-based programming and the next on AdvantageKit—might lead to greater success. We hope this helps!

link_counts.title: FRC1076 - Switching to Java Notes - Google Docs

posts.name: Chima Okafor
posts.cooked: Thank you so much for the advice; this will be so helpful. Wishing us luck for our transition.

Our team transitioned from Java to Python this year, just like you. Despite different experiences, the core principles remain the same. Last year, while most programming students focused on the comp bot, my friend and I (both sophomores) started by developing the swerve drive system. We then moved on to other components until we successfully programmed the entire comp bot in Python. Many of the concepts from Java stuck with us, and a senior with Java experience joined us, allowing us to achieve smooth progress.

posts.name: 0ri Korngut?
posts.cooked: Is there an advantage to Java beyond community resources?

posts.name: YehudaRothstein
posts.cooked: Java, unlike other programming languages, has broad support for libraries such as WPILib and other types of programs and applications. Additionally, Java excels in object-oriented programming, which contributes to command-based development and makes [FRC] (FIRST Robotics Competition) easy and effective.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Python has a terrible lambda syntax, and no multiline lambdas.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: Definitely, it’s mostly not a problem unless you’re using a framework designed around that paradigm, like commands.
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: In the context of programming languages, Java, unlike some others, has broader library support, particularly through libraries like WPILib. While Java, C++, and Python all have similar levels of support for such tools, the situation often differs depending on the specific use case. In the FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) world, this is evident as vendors play a larger role, providing significant support primarily for Java and limited assistance for other languages. Outside of FRC environments, language support can vary widely, with Java standing out due to its strong object-oriented programming capabilities, which align with command-based development practices in FRC, making it both effective and easy to use. Similarly, Java, C++, and Python all offer robust support for object-oriented programming.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
In 2025, Java remains the de facto standard for many Java teams, as it has been designed around the command paradigm. However, when looking to teach programming, particularly to newcomers, a more gradual approach is often better. This is why I firmly believe in "do what your local experts have the most experience with." If there are no local experts, Java would be the recommended choice.

The key is to minimize the amount of new material being introduced at once. Many new programmers are learning "how to program a robot," which is a distinct skill from "how to use programming language X." Separating these two can significantly improve learning outcomes. For this reason, transitioning languages over the summer, on the same robot you already understand, is preferable to making changes during build season.

We switched from Java to Python for precisely this reason. Our existing local experts and students were more familiar with Python, leading to better collaboration and productivity. This shift has allowed us to focus more on the unique aspects of FRC (FIRST Robotics Competition). Additionally, our history as a timed-robot team meant that the differences in command syntax between Python and Java weren't a significant barrier.
